p:
Children born to HIV-1-infected mothers are in 10–40% of the cases also infected by the virus (Kozlowski et al. 1993). These children develop symptoms before the age of 2 years.
About 30% of the HIV-1 children develop opportunistic infection or HIV-1 encephalopathy within the first year of life.
Brain growth is impaired leading to intellectual deficiency.
The gross-anatomical analysis shows brains which are too small for the age.
Sometimes atrophic gyri may be noted.
Microcephaly and/or brain atrophy is present.
The most common findings in brains of HIV-1-infected children are
Mineralization of predominantly small vessels found in 95% of the case.
Myelin pallor and gliosis are the noted changes of the white matter that occur in 78% of the cases.
MGC are seen in 62% of HIV-1-infected children.
Opportunistic infections are comparatively uncommon.
